title: Change in electric potential energy of system

content.question: A student has an isolated system of charged particles. The student wants to calculate the change <math alttext="delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the electric potential energy of the system between two instants in time but cannot do that directly, since the student does not have any information about the magnitude of the charges. Which of the following correctly describes a mathematical routine, if any, that can be used to determine <math alttext="delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>? Gravitational effects are negligible.

choices.label: Calculate the change <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><mi>K</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the total kinetic energy of the particles. This will be equal to <math alttext="negative delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Calculate the change <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><mi>K</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the total kinetic energy of the particles. This will be equal to <math alttext="delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Calculate the average kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub average " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>avg</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of the particles during the time interval between the two instants. This will be equal to <math alttext="delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The change in electric potential energy of the system cannot be determined without knowing the magnitudes of the charges.

content.answer: Calculate the change <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>Δ</mi><mi>K</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the total kinetic energy of the particles. This will be equal to <math alttext="negative delta U sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
